drawback_ecaw: This seems like an excellent proposition, although the exploratory phase could be difficult if the research question examines a sub-sample that is small. I think there would need to be flexibility in the extent to which an approach like this would be mandatory, to account for different sorts of research questions.

unsure_explain:
Q1: If ALSPAC required that I use an ECAW, this would not put me off using ALSPAC hence (hence 'strongly disagree')

Q4: If I have understood correctly, one issue I see with ECAW is that researchers can dredge the preliminary data for promising results before preregistering and getting the final full dataset, so doesn't necessarily stop some of the questionable research practices (p-hacking, HARKing, etc.) that pre-registration aims to overcome. Hence why, given the choice, I would prefer standard preregistration.
drawback_ecaw:
My main reservation, mentioned previously, is that an ECAW doesn't necessarily protect against p-hacking, fishing and HARKing. Perhaps an initial pre-registration prior to receiving the preliminary data, which can then be updated after the exploratory phase, might help get around this - But then that means more work as essentially it's both a full preregistrations and an ECAW!

I can definitely see the benefit of an ECAW in terms of using the preliminary data to produce and finalise analysis scripts, however.
suggestions: Most organisations like ALSPAC - with good reason - do not allow researchers to made data publicly-available. This hinders both open-ness and reproducibility. A system to make de-anonymised cohort data openly available would be really useful, I feel (e.g., making synthetic datasets which are anonymised but still maintain the structure and relations of the original data - such as via 'synthpop' package in R).
contact: Yes. (After completing the survey, you will be automatically redirected to another form and asked to enter your email address. There will be no link between your responses to this survey and your email address).

drawback_ecaw: I think this is a good idea and would be happy to use this (without any incentives). There may be times when changes would need to be made to the preregistered script (due to certain analytical problems that weren’t foreseen/ discovered with the random sample) but as long as changes could be made and documented, this would be fine. Also, the random sample would need to be large enough to be able to develop a script for complex analyses. One final consideration is how this would work for time limited projects such as using ALSPAC data for MSc projects. Some thought would be needed for whether the MSc student would be responsible for pre registering the script using the random sample, or if there would be exceptions to workflow for these kind of scenarios.
suggestions: Making code freely available (in supplement of paper or an online platform such as GitHub) could be a optional (or required) tick box on the ALSPAC publication checklist.

unsure_explain: I don't really have strong feelings on the matter, but if this is what ALSPAC decides I wouldn't argue
drawback_ecaw:
I'd want the admin process of obtaining the small sample data to not delay things (e.g. the small sample and the full sample could be generated by the data team at the same time).

My concern is that some techniques I use, like imputation models, may work in the small data set then the code fail to work in the complete data set (if e.g. variables were revealed to be colinear in the full sample analyses), so I think it would be naive to assume the small sample analysis would  seamlessly apply to the full sample analysis. 

On reflection, it would be frustrating if something that I'd spent time refining in the small sample didn't run in the large sample, and I had to re-do all the work. I think this would happen in the majority of analyses I run, and would delay my work.
comments: Didn't know anything about the ECAW concept going in so I haven't had much time to think it through

concerned: as concerned as a typical researcher in my field

drawback_ecaw:
incentives: maybe a data-access cost reduction
benefits: it's difficult to anticipate data problems using the traditional prereg approach. With ECAW, it's easier to see what the challenges might be (e.g. likely amount of missing data, data distribution issues, concrete variable coding)
drawbacks: sounds cumbersome (even if it's not)
reservations: you can probably still cheat the system

drawback_ecaw: My main concern is that the code may need to be readjusted to make it work for the full dataset, so I'm not entirely sure this process is better.

unsure_explain: This sounds like a positive and pragmatic way to reduce data dreding in some experiments, especially those where the hypothesis is broad or the analysis plan is not well described. In some cases the hypothesis and test are already very clear (for example, if looking to contribe to a genetic association study consortium), so I'm not sure this would be needed in all cases.

Either ways use of governed pre-existing data is not a fishing expedition. I really don't see much difference. However, I do support a catalogue of projects, where a new (or old) investigator sees what is already underway and can either readjust aims or ask for possibility to join in.
A real advancement in observational reports would be to start asking validation in another dataset, the same way that is carried out (required) in genomic studies.
drawback_ecaw: It would be great if a project statistician would run the final scripts. It would make a searchable, indexed library doable. It could be used by other investigators and anyone interested in research integrity or openness.
suggestions: Combinations of similar datasets would be wonderful. Then a validation/replication type analyses would be possible straight away. No that much need to wait for someone else to replicate findings in their, possibly quite different, dataset.

drawback_ecaw:
I can imagine this workflow could be difficult for analyses with smaller sample sizes, and/or lots of covariates or a complex model. This is because you might need much of your sample size to do the exploring. 
I also think there is a risk of people using the initial 500 (or whatever N) to actually decide on variables to include on the basis of significance - and this would be really problematic and should not be done - am not sure how you would stop people doing this.
I think there would still need to be a pre-registered analysis plan, before seeing the subset of the data. Then the subset is used to actually write and test the code, rather than to decide on analysis steps.

contact: Yes. (After completing the survey, you will be automatically redirected to another form and asked to enter your email address. There will be no link between your responses to this survey and your email address).

unsure_explain: I'm not sure I understand what ALSPAC running a study on ECAWs would look like.
drawback_ecaw: An obvious benefit of ECAW to me is that it's hard to know what errors are in the data or what cleaning might be required in a dataset like ALSPAC until you've seen a subset of it - this means you could pre-register absolute nonsense and then have to run those analyses or you could fail to pre-register some exclusion criteria you really need in order to make sure you only have (for example) careful responders, and then be stuck using all the entries even though you know some are rubbish.
suggestions: From an open science perspective, a big 'reproducibility' issue is that datasets like ALSPAC are closed access - so other researchers can't reproduce your findings/check that they work/reinterpret them, without also paying the fees.

unsure_explain: We typically run GWAS analyses where we effectively compare >1 million categories (=number of independent common genetic variants) in a single analysis. I feel that in this type on analysis, researcher bias is less likely to play a big role, because the genetic variants are largely uncorrelated with each other and biasing your analysis to overfit for one variant will reduce the power for all other variants. Furthermore, the technical biases influencing GWAS results (population stratification, outlier phenotypes, etc) can only be detected with large sample sizes. I feel that in setting ECAW would add a lot of extra work without clear benefit. I do like the idea that it makes it compulsory to share analysis code.

concerned: as concerned as a typical researcher in my field

suggestions:
There is always the risk of multiple teams studying the same topic in publicly available data sets with risk of overlapping findings and efforts that could have been spent on other topics.

An easily searchable register could help, with information about which research questions are being studied with this data, which variables are used, who is conducting these analyses and whether there is scope to liaise with this team to discuss possible overlap, and exchange of knowledge/scripts.

unsure_explain: I'm unsure if 500 would be adequate for some analyses - e.g. complex MLM, specifying imputation models.  For example, I know from previous work that imputation models that work on a subset of data can then fail to converge on a larger sample (or vice versa).
concerned: as concerned as a typical researcher in my field

unsure_explain: I would be very happy to use ALSPAC in a ECAW setting. The more studies use ECAW the better it will be for science.
drawback_ecaw: There is always the possibility that data subset provided initially isn't representative of the full dataset, resulting in problems not anticipated by the prepared script, e.g. a pattern of missing values or technical artefact causing a statistical model to fail. This would actually be really informative about the dataset and about how to select a subset, but it would require some kind of protocol for verifying the type of error encountered and whether or not it is the kind that should allow revision and reanalysis. For these and other reasons, ECAW will likely significantly increase the workload for those providing ALSPAC data to users.

drawback_ecaw: Ultimately the statistical findings from retrospective studies of big data are largely hypothesis generating anyway. Rarely, however, are they pursued at a deeper or independent level. Furthermore, regardless of what is pre-registered or “ECAWed” a vast number of analyses are performed by a vast number of investigators and selectively presented, kind of like candidate gene studies but on steroids.
comments: This field has major problems but the solution to those is primarily in the domain of following through on statistical findings with more and better science. If anything, preregistration approaches probably hurt more than help. Unless it’s a clinical trial (whole different ballgame) whether a research study is pre registered has no impact on my confidence in it.

suggestions: Require code to be submitted upon conclusion of the study

The problem with ECAWs is that funders will not fund this time spend on ECAWs and thus researchers like me whose position is  dependent funded research would not be able to comply with ECAWs. 
You will retain the senior researchers whose position is not dependent on funded research but will loose/limit opportunities for ECR and middle level researchers.

Other than that I am a supported of ECAW as it will limit fishing expeditions by researchers
drawback_ecaw: as mentioned earlier. I would not mind this procedure if funding was available for the ECAW phase of the study.
suggestions:
I know this takes a lot of work and resources but it would be beneficial for the ALSPAC study that summary variables are created (and checked) by the central ALSPAC team, instead of all researchers doing this for their own individual project. 
This would limit the variables to be chosen by the researcher chosen appropriate variables for their project, but it would also ensure data quality as you are more sure that the summary variables are created according to scale guidelines. 
Also centrally you can take decision on how much of the item-missing data you would impute...instead of external/non-ALSPAC researchers taking different decisions on item-missing imputation. This could lead to somewhat different results as different missing replacement approaches were employed.

unsure_explain: Sometimes you may need to access data at speed, or for other reasons not use an ECAW - I think it should always be optional rather than a requirement.
drawback_ecaw: As in previous question - timeliness in situations where data may be needed rapidly. Work flows can be more complex than just analysing one set of data - often I re-use ALSPAC data for many analyses and know it well so does the ECAW actually protect trustworthiness in those cases? Not sure. I think it would need to be optional, and the incentive should be higher trust in your work rather than any material incentive. No more badges and stickers for papers!
suggestions:
Require people to share their code. Make an open repository with all the projects that people have sent ALSPAC back their derived datasets for, with the scripts available so people can see what data have already been produced and browse options. People can then connect their ALSPAC publications to a specific address in that repository where their scripts are kept, and make it much easier for others to request that specific dataset from ALSPAC instead of just having to say "data are available from ALSPAC through X process" if they want to try and reproduce analyses. 

Not require that we use SPSS to extract ALSPAC data. Please set up and document and R or Python workflow!

Reservations: some analyses use small subsets of data - would be challenging to implement this framework for those analyses. May discourage investigators if null associations in preliminary analysis - may not proceed to full analysis, which may affect publication bias.

Incentive: offer discounted data access fees for others who use this approach, provide clear guidelines and instructions for each step, and provide repository for posting syntax, etc. Incentivize publishing null results? Or provide a platform for sharing null results to prevent investigators asking the same question in the future?
suggestions:
Data management organizations could provide a repository for investigators to share their syntax - this is not currently required by many journals and would help with rigor and reproducibility for investigators using the same data sources. 

With existing data sources that publish data requests/proposals, sometimes it's unclear whether an investigator did not proceed with an approved analysis due to lack of funding/time or whether they proceeded with the analysis and did not publish, potentially due to null results. Asking investigators to clarify where submitted proposals stand and making that available would be helpful, maybe update the status of each proposal annually? (e.g., working to secure funding, analyzing data, working on manuscript, on hold, no longer pursuing, etc.)

Some of these decisions can only be made after seeing the entire dataset.

unsure_explain: It depends very much on the models used. In some cases the analysis on a subset of the data is fine but then does not work well with the full set of data because of the presence of outliers. Similarly, analysis on a small dataset might not work as there might not be sufficient units in a cell, whereas it would be fine when the whole data is available. I think that the ECAW model would not work for everyone.

drawback_ecaw:
Analysing a small subset of the data first could introduce bias when it comes to the analysis of the whole dataset. Suppose the subset is so small as to be incapable of giving meaningful answers, but gives a large (but highly imprecise) association in the researcher's expected direction. The temptation will be to see this as confirmation of their prior beliefs, which just needs confirming with greater sample size. This could then lead to analytical methods and publication decisions with the full dataset depending on whether the results fit the reinforced prior expectations.
Another issue is that the appropriate analytical approach might depend on the sample size.
suggestions: I sometimes develop my analysis plans on simulated data. This can have the same sample size as the real data and will not tease me with hints as to the result I might get to my research question. The problem is that the real data will sometimes have inconvenient patterns of missingness or (co-) distribution which I didn't simulate. Rather than providing subsets of the real data, could data providers supply synthetic data to researchers developing their analysis plans? They could make it more realistic than the researcher's own guesses but leave the main effect of interest null.
comments: I sometimes wonder how robust the linkage is of cohort members to subsequent events/data, especially in the UK without a single national ID number. If there is a degree of uncertainty, it might be helpful if variables indicating the linkage confidence were made available, for the purposes of sensitivity analysis.

unsure_explain: Would want to see this in practice and determine the merits / disadvantages in my own perspective

drawback_ecaw: Sometimes it's useful to have the full sample size that the main analysis will be run on. For example some software might be limited by sample size, eg. HYDRA or other computationally demanding methods. You may need to run it on a system that has more computing power, but perhaps it ran ok on a local computer but when presented with the full dataset it has problems. Finally, would it be a problem for getting models to converge? ie. Might find a suitable model for the subset of data but when trying to run on the full sample you find the model doesn't converge or does not fit well? Not sure if that would be a problem or not. Perhaps having the option of providing dummy data to have the same sample size/power could be useful?
concerned: as concerned as a typical researcher in my field

unsure_explain: Being able to do exploratory or data-driven analyses are also important.

suggestions: Better data on attrition and the resulting biases

concerned: as concerned as a typical researcher in my field

unsure_explain: Some analyses are exploratory, so follow-up questions arise depending on the outcome of the analyses.This might be hard to tackle in advance using the ECAW approach.

I have used the same set of requested variables for different research questions/analyses as part of a larger project. I could see how having to do ECAWs for each analysis could end up being laborious and too time consuming than the usual workflow, but it would depend on the exact policies I think. Otherwise I do find the prospect appealing for ensuring rigorous data without putting all of the onus on individual researchers.
drawback_ecaw: I have used the same set of requested variables for different research questions/analyses as part of a larger project. I could see how having to do ECAWs for each analysis could end up being laborious and too time consuming than the usual workflow, but it would depend on the exact policies I think. Otherwise I do find the prospect appealing for ensuring rigorous data without putting all of the onus on individual researchers. The main concern for me would simply be time.
suggestions: I like the policies that ALSPAC has in place, particularly in that there is a data buddy to contact to make sure data is being used appropriately and approval required for article submission. There are limitations to the pre-registration process, particularly in that it again increases the amount of time for individual researchers, making it less likely to occur, so the ECAW workflow seems like a much better policy.
